abstract.p: Mary Ramniceanu letter says she carefully plans what food and snacks to bring aboard airplane (S)

block.p: To the Editor: As a young girl growing up in southern Illinois, I made train trips to Chicago accompanied by a packed box lunch, usually fried chicken, cole slaw, hard-boiled eggs, loads of fruit or a generous slab of homemade cake.

Years later, with that culinary imprint, I plan my carry-on lunch for an airplane trip as carefully as I plan my wardrobe for the trip: a shrimp or lobster salad, a small tin of foie gras with crunchy baguette, or an ordinary but superb Black Forest ham sandwich on a delicious bread with a lemon bar or a gooey brownie for comfort food.

To the Editor: As a young girl growing up in southern Illinois, I made train trips to Chicago accompanied by a packed box lunch, usually fried chicken, cole slaw, hard-boiled eggs, loads of fruit or a generous slab of homemade cake.

Years later, with that culinary imprint, I plan my carry-on lunch for an airplane trip as carefully as I plan my wardrobe for the trip: a shrimp or lobster salad, a small tin of foie gras with crunchy baguette, or an ordinary but superb Black Forest ham sandwich on a delicious bread with a lemon bar or a gooey brownie for comfort food.
I would suggest that all the moaning about airline food cease. Plan ahead. It is well worth the effort.
